Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effect of Pay for Success Models on Social Service Provision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how policy makers develop and implement hybrid models of social service provision. Specifically, this project studies how Pay for Success (PFS), a public-private model for social programs, shapes state spending on specific populations in the United States. Under a PFS contract, private investors provide initial funding for a public program, which the government repays only if the program proves successful. The PFS model promises to meet citizen needs while minimizing costs, but it is not yet clear who benefits from these programs, who is left out, and how these decisions are made. This project aims to determine (1) whether the goals of PFS projects influence which populations ultimately benefit from these projects and (2) the consequences of the PFS model for the scope of social provision more broadly. Findings from this study will be useful to policymakers and public advocates as the implementation or modification of PFS programs is considered, and so will contribute to the general public well-being.

The analysis employs a comparative case study design to assess the effect of PFS structure on beneficiary populations across three social service domains. Data collection will be via interviews with public and private actors involved in the design and implementation of PFS programs. Two sets of comparisons will be made: (1) comparisons between PFS proposals that matriculate into social programs and PFS proposals that fail to launch; and (2) comparisons between PFS-structured social programs and traditional social programs within specific issue areas. The case comparisons will illustrate the relationship between the PFS models' cost-savings structure and the populations the model ultimately serves. They will also elucidate the ways in which the PFS model differs from traditional models of service provision in terms of cost and scope. In evaluating these outcomes, this project will contribute to research on public policy and public-private models of social service provision.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines how policy makers develop and implement hybrid models of social service provision. Specifically, this project studies how Social Impact Bonds (SIBs) (also called “Pay for Success” (PFS)), a public-private model for social programs, shapes state spending on specific populations in the United States. The SIB model stipulates the governments should only “pay for success:” under a SIB contract, private investors provide initial funding for a public program, which the government repays only if the program proves successful. Unlike other models of service provision, the SIB model is structured to create opportunities for government savings, as programs that meet their success benchmarks reduce the need for downstream public spending in the future. The SIB model promises to meet citizen needs while minimizing costs, but it is not yet clear who benefits from these programs, who is left out, and how these decisions are made. This project aims to determine (1) whether the goals of SIB projects influence which populations ultimately benefit from these projects and (2) the consequences of the SIB model for the scope of social provision more broadly.

Expectations for how SIB program structure will shape the characteristics of beneficiary populations are drawn from scholarship on social policy in the United States. To assess these expectations, this project draws upon qualitative data from in-depth interviews with public and private actors involved in the design and implementation of SIB programs. The analysis employs a comparative case study design to assess the effect of SIB structure on beneficiary populations within two social service domains and one infrastructure domain. This research finds that SIB programs are effective in securing state funding for the poor and at risk for the following reasons: 1) their structure of relying on private funders to cover up-front project costs enables agencies that are otherwise budget-constrained to take action quickly; 2) their innovative project structure, with roles for diverse participants, is met with enthusiasm by local officials interested in working across jurisdictions and organizations to solve social problems; and 3) their focus on evidence-based program designs cast SIB interventions as nonpartisan and mutually beneficial to a range of participants, regardless of partisan commitments.

More specifically, this research demonstrates that SIB projects ask local governments to accomplish an array of goals at once: to meet the needs of vulnerable individuals; to steward government funds carefully, with cost savings as a central goal; and to produce high-quality research products concerning program efficacy. Aligning social, financial, and academic goals creates a range of administrative and ethical challenges for SIB programs and the actors who implement them: to restructure social programs around cost savings and to do so while also meeting state mandates to provide care; to develop program evaluations that privilege scientific rigor without sacrificing service-provider ethics; and to translate project goals, activities, and outcomes across a wide array of jurisdictions and areas of expertise. The project illustrates how two project teams ably navigate these challenges while the third fails to do so, resulting in communication breakdown and unresolved problems in program measurement. The causes of this failure are complex: poor project oversight, porous boundary management regarding the allocation of project tasks, and the outsized influence of project elites, whose political authority shaped project development often in unexpected ways.

This project contributes to research on social policy and public-private models of social service provision. Patterns of privatization and the retrenchment of social benefits pose a serious risk to the nation’s neediest citizens. Over the past half-century, these populations have seen state support diminish. The SIB offers a model for state action that has the potential to allocate resources to those in need, but it is not clear who benefits from the SIB framework, who is left out, and how this political work is accomplished. This project strives to resolve such questions and to share the knowledge created with policymakers and advocates through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and policy memos. In so doing, the project helps facilitate open conversation about the SIB framework and arms political actors with evidence to build social programs that empower rather than marginalize those most in need.
